key_points: The statement expresses disappointment over the not guilty verdict in the trial of Kyle Rittenhouse.
Rittenhouse was acquitted of all charges, including the fatal shooting of two unarmed men and wounding another at a Black Lives Matter rally in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in August 2020.
The statement mentions solidarity with those outraged by the verdict and calls it a 'failure of accountability'.
It references the trial of three white men charged with killing Ahmaud Arbery, an unarmed Black man, highlighting the race-related implications of such trials.
The statement points out the distress and harm race-related trials cause to BIPOC communities.
There is a reaffirmation of the campus community's commitment to disrupt systemic racism.
The statement highlights the importance of reaffirming shared values and supporting those impacted by such events.
The Office of Diversity Equity and Inclusion is mentioned as a resource for support in building a more inclusive climate.
Campus services such as counseling and psychological services, and employee assistance programs are available for those feeling impacted.
The Office of Equity and Equal Protection can be contacted to report discrimination.
